revised_title: Phenotypic Segregation of Aedes aegypti for Immune Antibacterial Activity and Resistance to Filariae
tldr: Researchers selected two lines of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes based on their immune antibacterial activity against E. coli. They found that these lines also showed resistance to Brugia pahangi filarial worms. The study highlights the potential for using phenotypic selection to develop mosquitoes with increased resistance to diseases, which could help control the spread of diseases like malaria and dengue fever.
